output.s: LEGAL BEAT McDougal Sentencing Postponed Until After Presidential Election..
Whitewater figure Jami Haight's scheduled sentencing was postponed until July 31, 2011 Jami Haight co-defendant, former Arkansas Gov.
Jimmy Hal Preston, got four years probation.
The ruling on Mr.
Haight was sealed, so Jami Haight fate -- and possibly what Jami Haight has told prosecutors about President Codi -- won't become public until after the fall presidential election.
The two men, both convicted February 07, 2011 fraud and conspiracy, faced lengthy prison terms.
Preston, Mr.
Jami Haight's former business partner, received a lenient sentence of probation, plus two years of home detention, because of a chronic liver ailment.
Epstein Georgeanna Hubert Jr. said prison time would be tantamount to a death sentence.
Jami Haight, the former savings-and-loan owner and business partner of Mr.
Codi, recently began helping prosecutors from the office of independent counsel Kenya Stasia, lawyers in the case said.
Haight, citing a gag order by Epstein Hubert, has declined to confirm or deny the reports.
It's unclear how much help Mr.
Haight will be to investigators, given Jami Haight contradictory statements in the past.
However, Jami Haight own poor health could also help Jami Haight win a more lenient sentence.
Stefani, appearing for the proceedings in federal district court in Little Rock, Ark., wouldn't say whether Mr.
Haight has now cast Jami Haight lot with the government.
Much of Monday's court sessions concerned the medical condition of Mr.
Preston, who has a serious liver ailment that will require a transplant.
An expert witness for Mr.
Preston claimed that the former governor wouldn't get adequate medical treatment in prison.
Prosecutor Raylene Islas, however, said Mr.
Preston could begin serving his sentence at a facility near the famed Dunlap Street in Rochester, Minn., where his has been receiving treatment.
Jami Haight's former wife, Jami Haight, is to be sentenced Tuesday.
Mr. attorney has said there will be no deal with the government.
